fields.label_text:
Communion Chalice and Paten

This magnificent chalice was used during Holy Communion to serve the consecrated wine. It was donated to St Mary’s Lambeth by the rector, Dr Daniel Featley, and is typical of the style recommended by William Laud, the Archbishop of Canterbury. 

Laud regarded the Anglican church as a purified form of traditional Catholicism. He set out to restore the ceremonial that had been abolished with the Reformation of the previous century, including the high altar and the use of candles and incense. Parliament saw this as an attempt to overthrow the Protestant religion and in 1645 Laud was beheaded.

Dr Featley was opposed to Archbishop Laud’s reforms and resisted his request to restore the high altar, yet his chalice is based on the late medieval models that Laud preferred.

London, England, 1638–9; maker’s mark ‘GM’ and
a martlet. Silver gilt
Lent by the Vicar and Churchwardens of St Mary’s
Lambeth

fields.descriptive_line: A silver-gilt communion chalice and paten presented to St. Mary's Lambeth by Dr. Daniel Featley in 1639.

fields.name: The Anglican Church
fields.venue: Sacred Silver and Stained Glass Galleries, the Victoria and Albert Museum

fields.physical_description: The bowl is round, the stem hexagonal, divided by a moulded knop, and the foot splayed with a moulded ornament with cherub's head at each point, with an egg and tongue moulding round the splayed part
fields.dimensions:
Diameter: 14 cm
[cover (closure)] Diameter: 12 cm, Height: 4.5 cm
[Communion chalice] Height: 24 cm, Diameter: 13 cm
fields.label:
Communion Chalice and Paten

This magnificent chalice was used during Holy Communion to serve the consecrated wine. It was donated to St Mary’s Lambeth by the rector, Dr Daniel Featley, and is typical of the style recommended by William Laud, the Archbishop of Canterbury. 

Laud regarded the Anglican church as a purified form of traditional Catholicism. He set out to restore the ceremonial that had been abolished with the Reformation of the previous century, including the high altar and the use of candles and incense. Parliament saw this as an attempt to overthrow the Protestant religion and in 1645 Laud was beheaded.

Dr Featley was opposed to Archbishop Laud’s reforms and resisted his request to restore the high altar, yet his chalice is based on the late medieval models that Laud preferred.

London, England, 1638–9; maker’s mark ‘GM’ and
a martlet. Silver gilt
Lent by the Vicar and Churchwardens of St Mary’s
Lambeth [22/11/2005]
fields.location: Sacred Silver & Stained Glass, room 83, case 2b
fields.marks:
In a heart-shaped stamp, with an inner dotted line following the shape of the stamp, OM , a bird below

The chalice is inscribed 'Hunc Calicem Sacrum donavit Joycea Featley Obijt Octob:29.1637
Donum sacruit Daniel Featley DD Rector Lambethae' and engraved with the coat of arms 'Or, a lion rampant sa. between three fleurs-de-lys az., for Fairclough of London, impaling Arg.,fretty gu., on a chief az. three fleurs-de-lys or for Coyner of London.

The paten has the sacred monogram 'IHS' on the flat of the foot.  This sacred chalice was given for Joyce Featley who died 29 October 1637. The gift was consecrated by Daniel Featley, Doctor of Divinity and Rector of Lambeth.
fields.public_access_description:
This magnificent chalice was used during Holy Communion to serve the consecrated wine. It was donated to St Mary’s Lambeth by the rector, Dr Daniel Featley, and is typical of the style recommended by William Laud, the Archbishop of Canterbury. 

Laud regarded the Anglican church as a purified form of traditional Catholicism. He set out to restore the ceremonial that had been abolished with the Reformation of the previous century, including the high altar and the use of candles and incense. Parliament saw this as an attempt to overthrow the Protestant religion and in 1645 Laud was beheaded.

Dr Featley was opposed to Archbishop Laud’s reforms and resisted his request to restore the high altar, yet his chalice is based on the late medieval models that Laud preferred.
fields.exhibition_history: The Anglican Church (Sacred Silver and Stained Glass Galleries, the Victoria and Albert Museum 22/11/2005-22/11/2005)
fields.bibliography: Cooper, T.S. (Rev) <u>The Church Plate of Surrey</u>, Guildford, Surrey Archaeological Society, 1902, pp.273-275
fields.credit: Lent by the Vicar and Churchwardens of St. Mary's Lambeth
fields.history_note:
This chalice and paten were given by Dr. Daniel Featley, rector of St. Mary's Lambeth in 1639. He was descended from a Lancashire family named Fairclough but changed his name to Featley. This explains the identity of the coat of arms on the chalice.  The chalice and paten are based on the medieval models that Archbishop Laud preferred.

Historical significance: Dr. Daniel Featley was appointed to the living of St. Mary's Lambeth in 1618-1619. He opposed Archbishop Laud's reforms and resisted his request to restore the high altar, but the chalice is typical of the Laudian style.  Featley stood as a witness against Laud at his trial. In 1642 he was appointed one of the Assembly of Divines by Parliament, but withdrew and was deprived of his living.  He was subsequently imprisoned and died in 1645. He was buried in the chancel of St. Mary's Lambeth on 21st April 1645.
fields.historical_context_note:
The Anglican Church
In 1633 William Laud became Archbishop of Canterbury. Like his contemporary Bishop Lancelot Andrewes, he regarded the Anglican church as a purified form of traditional Catholicism. Together they set out to restore the ceremonial that had been abolished with the Reformation of the previous century, including the high altar and the use of candles and incense.

Laud’s intentions, however, were seen by Parliament as an attempt to overthrow the Protestant religion and in 1645 he was beheaded. It was not until the restoration of the monarchy in 1660 that churches could again use a Gothic chalice and celebrate the Eucharist with an elaborately chased and decorated communion set.
